      • setSecret

        public ApiKeyBuilder setSecret(String secret)
        Description copied from interface: ApiKeyBuilder
        Allows specifying the client's API Key secret value directly instead of relying on the default location + override/fallback behavior defined in the documentation above.

        Usage Warning

        It is strongly recommended that you never embed raw API Key secret values in source code! API Key Secret values are tied to an individual person and should never be shared with anyone or embedded in source code that can be viewed by multiple people. For example:

        THIS IS AN ANTI-PATTERN! DO NOT DO THIS! THIS IS A SECURITY RISK! 

         String id = "myRawApiKeyId";
 String secret = "secretValueThatAnyoneCouldSeeIfTheyCheckedOutMySourceCode";
 ApiKey apiKey = ApiKeys.builder().setId(id).setSecret(secret).build();
 Client client = Clients.builder().setApiKey(apiKey).build();

        Because of this, it is recommended to rely on the default location + override/fallback behavior defined in the documentation above. However, if the default environment variable or system property names are not suitable, and you would prefer to use your own names, or you would prefer to obtain your secret value in a different secure manner, setting this property explicitly can be useful. For example:

         String id = System.getenv("MY_STORMPATH_API_KEY_ID"); //alternative (non-default) env var name
 String secret = System.getenv("MY_STORMPATH_API_KEY_SECRET"); //alternative (non-default) env var name
 ApiKey apiKey = ApiKeys.builder().setId(id).setSecret(secret).build();
 Client client = Clients.builder().setApiKey(apiKey).build();
        Specified by:
        setSecret in interface ApiKeyBuilder
        Parameters:
        secret - the ApiKey id to use when communicating with Stormpath.
        Returns:
        the ApiKeyBuilder instance for method chaining.
        See Also:
        ApiKeyBuilder.setId(String), ClientBuilder.setApiKey(com.stormpath.sdk.api.ApiKey)

      • setFileLocation

        public ApiKeyBuilder setFileLocation(String location)
        Description copied from interface: ApiKeyBuilder
        Sets the location of the .properties file to load containing the API Key (Id and secret) used by the Client to communicate with the Stormpath REST API.

        You may load files from the filesystem, classpath, or URLs by prefixing the location path with file:, classpath:, or url: respectively. If no prefix is found, file: is assumed by default.

        File Contents

        When the file is loaded, the following name/value pairs are expected to be present by default:

        Key Value
        apiKey.id An individual account's API Key ID
        apiKey.secret The API Key Secret (password) that verifies the paired API Key ID.

        Assuming you were using these default property names, your ClientBuilder usage might look like the following: 

         String location = "/home/jsmith/.stormpath/apiKey.properties";

 ApiKey apiKey = ApiKeys.builder().setFileLocation(location).build();
 Client client = Clients.builder().setApiKey(apiKey).build();

        Custom Property Names

        If you want to control the property names used in the file, you may configure them via setIdPropertyName and setSecretPropertyName.

        For example, if you had a /home/jsmith/.stormpath/apiKey.properties file with the following name/value pairs: 

         myStormpathApiKeyId = foo
 myStormpathApiKeySecret = mySuperSecretValue
        Your ClientBuilder usage would look like the following: 
         String location = "/home/jsmith/.stormpath/apiKey.properties";

 Client client =
     Clients.builder()
     .setApiKey(
          ApiKeys.builder()
          .setFileLocation(location)
          .setIdPropertyName("myStormpathApiKeyId")
          .setSecretPropertyName("myStormpathApiKeySecret")
          .build())
     .build();
        Specified by:
        setFileLocation in interface ApiKeyBuilder
        Parameters:
        location - the file, classpath or url location of the API Key .properties file to load when constructing the API Key to use for communicating with the Stormpath REST API.
        Returns:
        the ApiKeyBuilder instance for method chaining.

      • build

        public ApiKey build()
        Description copied from interface: ApiKeyBuilder
        Constructs a new ApiKey instance based on the ApiKeyBuilder's current configuration state. This method loads (and overrides) ID and secret values from the following locations, in order:
        1. The default apiKey.properties file location of System.getProperty("user.home") + "/.stormpath/apiKey.properties" as recommended/documented in the Stormpath Java Quickstart.
        2. A properties file that exists at the file path or URL specified by the STORMPATH_API_KEY_FILE environment variable. If this file exists and contains either the apiKey id or secret properties, these values override any values found in the default apiKey.properties file. The STORMPATH_API_KEY_FILE String can be an absolute file path, or it can be a URL or a classpath value by using the url: or classpath: prefixes respectively.
        3. The environment variables STORMPATH_API_KEY_ID and STORMPATH_API_KEY_SECRET. If either of these values are present, they override any previously discovered value.
        4. A properties file that exists at the file path or URL specified by the stormpath.client.apiKey.file system property. If this file exists and any values are present, the values override any previously discovered value. The stormpath.client.apiKey.file system property String can be an absolute file path, or it can be a URL or a classpath value by using the url: or classpath: prefixes respectively.
        5. The system properties stormpath.client.apiKey.id and stormpath.client.apiKey.secret. If either of these values are present, they override any previously discovered values.
        6. A specified fileLocation: Any properties discovered in this .properties file will override any previously automatically discovered values. The fileLocation String can be an absolute file path, or it can be a URL or a classpath value by using the url: or classpath: prefixes respectively.
        7. A specified inputStream: Properties discovered while reading the input stream will override any previously discovered values.
        8. A specified reader: Properties discovered after reading the Reader will override any previously discovered values.
        9. A specified properties instance: Properties discovered in the instance will override any previously discovered values.
        10. Directly specified id and secret property values. If specified, they will override any previously discovered value.
        Specified by:
        build in interface ApiKeyBuilder
        Returns:
        a new ApiKey instance based on the ApiKeyBuilder's current configuration state.
